description: On May 8, the Ministry of Health of Guatemala (MSPAS) denounces a report as false news, stating, "That FUNDESA on its social networks made a publication of the Monitoring Report of the Health Commission where it reflects that MSPAS has not made the necessary purchases of protective equipment to attend the emergency of COVID-19, however this information Is false."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 12, the Ministry of Health in Guatemala denounced a report by the Health Defender's Office, of the Human Rights Ombudsman's Office -PDH- indicating that "That six resident doctors at the Chimaltenango Hospital have not been diagnosed with COVID-19, as made known by the PDH. MSPAS confirms that two doctors tested positive for the new virus."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On May 13, the Ministry of Health of Guatemala warned against the spread of images of doctors wearing trash bags in a COVID-19 temporary hospital due to a lack of protective equipment, calling it fake news. 
"It has been made to believe that this photo belongs to the Parque de la Industria Temporary Hospital, which treats patients diagnosed with COVID-19, however, the Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance clarifies that this photo does NOT belong to that care center."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On April 6th, Guatemala announces that schools cannot expel or sanction students during the coronavirus emergency. The Ministry of Economy specified that private schools will not be able to charge fines, arrears or interest to parents who fall behind in their students' tuition payments.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
type_text: Schools cannot expel or sanction, charge fines or interest to  students during the coronavirus emergency.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Guatemala, October 1. The Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance issued guidelines for higher education institutions and technical training centers to go back to classes. These guidelines depend on the alert color of each individual municipality. The guidelines include: practicing social distancing, protocols to carry out field research, protocols to detect people with COVID-19 symptoms and protocols for hybird classes.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)

description: Guatemala, December 15. The Ministry of Education announced the reopening of schools in all levels of education, in the private sector for January 4th; in the public sector for February 15th. Educational institutions will be allowed to open in-person if the alert level is in orange, yellow or green. If the alert level is in red, educational institutions will operate remotely.

The curfew is from 4:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m. and is scheduled to be in effect until March 29. Everyone in Guatemala, including foreigners, is expected to remain in their homes during curfew hours. The only exceptions are for police, private security, medical professionals and ambulances, food delivery drivers, and certain other essential personnel

description: Starting May 15 2020, Guatemala is alternating between an all day stay-at-home lockdown during the weekend (Friday May 15 to Sunday May 17) and a curfew during the week days (Monday May 18 to Thursday May 21). This curfew is from 9:00PM to 4AM relaxing the previous chain of curfews that were around 5:00PM or 6:00PM to 5:00AM. The end date for this policy has not been announced.

description: Guatemala, August 12. The President announced that a nationwide curfew will take effect. The curfew will be from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. and is scheduled to be in effect from August 13 to August 23. individuals are required to stay at home or in their accommodation. The only exceptions are for essential personnel, including police, private security, medical professionals, and food-delivery drivers. The Guatemalan police and security forces will enforce the curfew. Those in breach of the curfew may be subject to a fine or imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week

description: On January 31st, Guatemala declares a National Emergency and limits entry by air, land and sea to any foreign person who has visited China in the last 15 days.Guatemala allows the admission of any Guatemalan person who has remained in China however, they must comply with the established health protocol, which includes: interview, clinical evaluation, and if necessary, transfer to a MSPAS health service, for proper isolation and treatment. The end date of the policy was not announced.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 31st, Guatemala announces that the Minister of National Defense to assist the measured implemented by the Ministry of Public Health will monitor seaports and ships entering Guatemalan waters that arrive from Asia. The collection of relevant travel information and the health monitoring of all crew members will be done by the army. Cargo can still be unloaded but crew members are not allowed to exit the boats.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: On March 16, Guatamala closed its borders to every country. Nobody can enter the country except for guatemalans, permanent residents and diplomats.. Special charter flights for citizens of different countries to go back home are allowed. The original measure was set to last until March 31, they were extended everytime there was a new presidential disposition but the content of the policy remained unchanged. It was extended on: April 12, April 20, April 27, May 4, May 11, May 15, May 25, May 31, June 4, June 7, June 14, June 28, July 12, July 26, August 6 and August 25. The end date in the last time extension was unspecified. UPDATE: The original quarantine was set to last until March 31, it has been extended to April 12.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Guatemala's Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance of the Republic of Guatemala (MSPAS) announces that travellers from Wuhan, China, with respiratory symptoms are being monitored (at the kiosk?). 
All patients in the country with severe respiratory infections are under observation. 
Mechanisms of "internal coordination" between the MSPAS and other agencies have been "activated." UPDATE: Guatemala's Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance of the Republic of Guatemala (MSPAS) further explains what measures have been taken to monitor the epidemic related to the kiosk at La Aurora airport.

description: On May 23, 2020 the government of Guatemala announced a nationwide lockdown from 1700 (23:00 GMT) Friday, May 23 until 0500 Monday, May 26th, 2020. The only activity permitted is the distribution of food and medication or the circulation of health professionals or essential workers.

description: Guatemala, May 24. description: On May 10th, in Guatemala, the Ministry of Health instituted a "cordon sanitaire" (community lockdown) in  Monte Carmelo II, a village in Lo De Mejía, San Juan Sacatepéquez. description:
Guatemala, April 1st. The Congress of the Republic publishes the Decree 12-2020, which approves the Emergency Law to Protect Guatemalans from the Effects Caused by the Coronavirus COVID-19 Pandemic.
The purpose of this temporary law is to create the necessary measures to deal with the crisis resulting from the measures adopted to contain and mitigate the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic in the national territory.

description: On May 25th, "the Government of Guatemala made official the creation of the Presidential Commission for Emergency Care Covid-19 (Coprecovid)." The entity, which includes other ministries and private groups, aims to support and advise on everything related to the actions of the Ministry of Public Health. Coprecovid must advise and recommend measures for the prevention, containment and mitigation of Covid-19, to be implemented by the Ministry of Health. Its mandate will last at least 1 year.

description:
On April 30th, the Ministry of Health of Guatemala confirms that by Government Decree Number 5-2020 and Resolution CN-06-3-2020, the institutions working against Covid19 have the responsibility of receiving and registering national donations and to inform CONRED weekly on Mondays, 2 pm at the latest, and at the request of CONRED any time.
CONRED will then inform the Ministerio de Finanzas Públicas. 
Donations will be coordinated only by the Ministry of Foreign Relations and CONRED.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: All institutions working to contain Covid19 in Guatemala must report all donations to CONRED at least once weekly.

description: On March 31st, the Ministry of Education in Guatemala starts television classes from 9am to 1:30pm for all elementary school children as part of the #AprendoEnCasa initiative. The initiative is accompanied by educational support material for students that will be published in national newspapers and on social networks and are available on the ministry's website. Paper copies of these self-learning guides will be distributed in the coming weeks.

On April 5th, Guatemala undertook "the delivery of food boxes, called "Kits Juntos Saldremos Adelante", was started, destined to a total of 200 thousand families vulnerable by the coronavirus Covid-19."
Each box weighs about 36 pounds and was reported to contain eight products, including sugar, beans, pasta, cornmeal, and oil, among others.

description:
On April 14th, it is announced that the Ministry of Education in Guatemala will distribute self-learning guides and booklets for students and parents.
The guides will be reproduced for the different levels in Spanish and in ten Mayan languages: Achí, Chortí, Chuj, Ixil, Kaqchikel, K'iche', Mam, Q'anjob'al, Q'eqchí and Tz'utujil. There will be around 36,200 printed total for elementary school students.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
On April 17th, it is announced that the Ministry of Education in Guatemala has established strategy points for college students' education post-quarantine:
1) Making a diagnostic evaluation of the students at the time of resuming the school year, to find out how much knowledge they managed to achieve during the quarantine
2) Evaluations will take place to evaluate competencies and skills, not content
3) The school term will be extended to compensate for the missed class time
4) The ministry will establish what learning is the most essential and fundamental for the student to acquire and ask schools to focus on it.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

● Avoiding contact with sick people
● Attending a health service, if you have symptoms, such as high fever, cough and difficulty breathing.

description:
On June 3rd in Guatemala, as part of the new Guide of recommendations for the operation of markets and public squares for the prevention of covid-19, the following measures will be followed in the canteens:
To have a hand washing station at the entrance, with liquid soap
Install automatic or pedal water faucets and automatic soap dispensers
1.5 meter distance between people
Maximum 20 minutes stay per person
Self-service is prohibited in the dining rooms
No presentation of uncoated food is allowed

description:
On June 3rd in Guatemala,  as part of the new Guide of recommendations for the operation of markets and public squares for the prevention of covid-19, the following measures will be followed when entering market places: 
Only one adult per family enters
Children under the age of 15 are prohibited from entering
Enable exclusive access for two hours, three days a week, for those over 60 
Everyone who enters will have their temperature taken
Disinfectant mats and vinyl posters should be installed
Close the perimeter, leaving one entrance and one exit
Painting on the floor where each stall will be located

description:
On June 3rd in Guatemala, as part of the new Guide of recommendations for the operation of markets and public squares for the prevention of covid-19, the following measures will be followed when inside the market places:
"Cleaning at least three times a day
Permanent disinfection of stands, baskets, tables, handrails and doors
The washing should be done with a 5% solution of water with chlorine and quaternary ammonium
Gel dispensers at the sales stands
Certification to those who package, transport, sell, prepare and serve food
Sales stand covered with transparent plastic
Voicing is prohibited; prices, by means of posters
No food consumption at points of sale"

description:
On June 3rd in Guatemala, as part of the new Guide of recommendations for the operation of markets and public squares for the prevention of covid-19, the following measures will be followed when a seller is suspected of being sick. 
Fill out the symptom information sheet and isolate the person
Have a place of isolation and call 1540 and 1517 of the Ministry of Health
Cover the suspect's position with a wet plastic, 5% chlorine solution in water
Do not give precautionary notices, to avoid panic and misinformation

description: As part of its State of Calamity decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will prevent gatherings of people and to prohibit or suspend all kinds of public performances and all kinds of meetings or events that represent a risk to health. Public shows, meetings or events scheduled for Saturday 7 and Sunday 8 March 2020 may be held without any interference, but from Monday 9 requests of authorization for any kind of event will have to be sent to the ministry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 10th, Guatemala informs the population that each person or public and/or private company that wants to carry out events with more than 150 people, must ask for authorization of the activity with 48 to 72 hours of anticipation in the Health Area of their locality. UPDATE: Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will prevent gatherings of people and to prohibit or suspend all kinds of public performances and all kinds of meetings or events that represent a risk to health. On March 10th it is specified that all events of 150+ people will only be allowed with prior authorization from the public health services.

On March 10th, Guatemala declares that due to the confusion surrounding mass events, notifying the health departments will be necessary, but no authorization will be issued, because, no case of COVID-19 has been confirmed in Guatemala as of yet. Notifications must be made online 48 hours to 72 hours prior to the event. UPDATE: On March 10th, Guatemala announced that all gatherings of 150+ people would need prior authorization from local health departments. Later in the day, the health ministry clarifies that the population will only need to notify health services and NOT ask for authorization. This will be done online and NOT in the local health department.

On March 10th, Guatemala informs the population that each person or public and/or private company that wants to carry out events with more than 150 people, must ask for authorization of the activity with 48 to 72 hours of anticipation in the Health Area of their locality.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On June 2nd, Guatemala activated a protocol for the phased re-opening of sports centres. A 'testing' period will last a week before actual reactivation of the sports centres. During this week, the following rules are applied:
Only prioritized athletes (1st, 2nd and 3rd line) determined by the FADN, coaches and technical support personnel will have access under a schedule.
During the sports activation phase for training processes, a schedule of 8am to 1pm will be established, with a maximum of 60 minutes per session. 
To comply with the protocol of hygiene and sanitization of entrance.
During the stay inside the facility, avoid any kind of physical contact according to the specific regulations by sport.
Wear a badge or card as well as a mask to enter and remain inside the facility.
Respect the rules of physical distance for sports and regulation of users by area.
It is prohibited to enter briefcases, bags, backpacks, as well as the use of cell phones during the training session.
Show up with sports clothes to use, towel and personal hygiene items.
No food is allowed, only a bottle with liquids will be allowed.
It is forbidden to share drinks or personal objects.
It is forbidden to spit and blow your nose inside the facility.
The use of showers, dressing rooms and drinking fountains is forbidden.
The use of air conditioners is not allowed.
Any equipment or material used during training must be disinfected before and after use.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 14th of June, Guatemala announces new restrictions on the circulation of vehicles depending on license plate numbers in the departments of Sacatepéquez, El Progreso and San Marcos. "On Tuesday, the plates whose numbering ends in even numbers: 0, 2, 4, 6 and 8 are in circulation. On Wednesday, the plates whose numbering ends in odd numbers are in circulation: 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9." And so on for the rest of the week, until the Sunday which is a complete lockdown apart from specified exemptions.These measures are set to last until at least June 28th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On the 14th of June, Guatemala announces new restrictions on the circulation of vehicles depending on license plate numbers in the departments of Sacatepéquez, El Progreso and San Marcos. "On Tuesday, the plates whose numbering ends in even numbers: 0, 2, 4, 6 and 8 are in circulation. On Wednesday, the plates whose numbering ends in odd numbers are in circulation: 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9." And so on for the rest of the week, until the Sunday which is a complete lockdown apart from specified exemptions.These measures are set to last until at least June 28th. UPDATE: Following the start of the car license plate policy on June 16th, "President Alejandro Giammattei announced that the plate restriction will continue for the next 15 days, but a new system will be used. If the date ends in an odd number, then vehicles with odd number plates will circulate on that day, but if the date ends in an even number, then the even number plates will be the ones that can circulate." The restriction will apply to the following departments: Guatemala, Sacatepéquez, Escuintla, and Quetzaltenango - but NOT San Marcos and El Progreso as before.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
